properties.description: The message to display when consecutive dialog protection is triggered. If not defined the default message would be used, note that currently the default message is in English and not localized.

properties.name: disableDialogs
properties.description: Whether to disable dialogs completely. Overrides `safeDialogs`. Default is `false`.

properties.name: navigateOnDragDrop
properties.description: Whether dragging and dropping a file or link onto the page causes a navigation. Default is `false`.

properties.name: autoplayPolicy
properties.description: Autoplay policy to apply to content in the window, can be `no-user-gesture-required`, `user-gesture-required`, `document-user-activation-required`. Defaults to `no-user-gesture-required`.

properties.name: disableHtmlFullscreenWindowResize
properties.description: Whether to prevent the window from resizing when entering HTML Fullscreen. Default is `false`.

properties.name: accessibleTitle
properties.description: An alternative title string provided only to accessibility tools such as screen readers. This string is not directly visible to users.

properties.name: spellcheck
properties.description: Whether to enable the builtin spellchecker. Default is `true`.

properties.name: enableWebSQL
properties.description: Whether to enable the WebSQL api. Default is `true`.

properties.name: v8CacheOptions
properties.description: Enforces the v8 code caching policy used by blink. Accepted values are

possibleValues.description: Disables code caching
Heuristic based code caching
Bypass code caching heuristics but with lazy compilation
Same as above except compilation is eager. Default policy is `code`.

properties.name: enablePreferredSizeMode
properties.description: Whether to enable preferred size mode. The preferred size is the minimum size needed to contain the layout of the document—without requiring scrolling. Enabling this will cause the `preferred-size-changed` event to be emitted on the `WebContents` when the preferred size changes. Default is `false`.

staticMethods.name: getAllWindows
staticMethods.description: An array of all opened browser windows.

staticMethods.name: getFocusedWindow
staticMethods.description: The window that is focused in this application, otherwise returns `null`.

staticMethods.name: fromWebContents
staticMethods.description: The window that owns the given `webContents` or `null` if the contents are not owned by a window.

staticMethods.name: fromBrowserView
staticMethods.description: The window that owns the given `browserView`. If the given view is not attached to any window, returns `null`.

instanceMethods.name: destroy
instanceMethods.description: Force closing the window, the `unload` and `beforeunload` event won't be emitted for the web page, and `close` event will also not be emitted for this window, but it guarantees the `closed` event will be emitted.

instanceMethods.name: close
instanceMethods.description: Try to close the window. This has the same effect as a user manually clicking the close button of the window. The web page may cancel the close though. See the close event.

instanceMethods.name: focus
instanceMethods.description: Focuses on the window.

instanceMethods.name: blur
instanceMethods.description: Removes focus from the window.

instanceMethods.name: isFocused
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window is focused.

instanceMethods.name: isDestroyed
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window is destroyed.

instanceMethods.name: show
instanceMethods.description: Shows and gives focus to the window.

instanceMethods.name: showInactive
instanceMethods.description: Shows the window but doesn't focus on it.

instanceMethods.name: hide
instanceMethods.description: Hides the window.

instanceMethods.name: isVisible
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window is visible to the user.

instanceMethods.name: isModal
instanceMethods.description: Whether current window is a modal window.

instanceMethods.name: maximize
instanceMethods.description: Maximizes the window. This will also show (but not focus) the window if it isn't being displayed already.

instanceMethods.name: unmaximize
instanceMethods.description: Unmaximizes the window.

instanceMethods.name: isMaximized
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window is maximized.

instanceMethods.name: minimize
instanceMethods.description: Minimizes the window. On some platforms the minimized window will be shown in the Dock.

instanceMethods.name: restore
instanceMethods.description: Restores the window from minimized state to its previous state.

instanceMethods.name: isMinimized
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window is minimized.

instanceMethods.name: setFullScreen
instanceMethods.description: Sets whether the window should be in fullscreen mode.

instanceMethods.name: isFullScreen
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window is in fullscreen mode.

instanceMethods.name: setSimpleFullScreen
instanceMethods.description:
Enters or leaves simple fullscreen mode.

Simple fullscreen mode emulates the native fullscreen behavior found in versions of macOS prior to Lion (10.7).

instanceMethods.name: isSimpleFullScreen
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window is in simple (pre-Lion) fullscreen mode.

instanceMethods.name: isNormal
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window is in normal state (not maximized, not minimized, not in fullscreen mode).

instanceMethods.name: setAspectRatio
instanceMethods.description:
This will make a window maintain an aspect ratio. The extra size allows a developer to have space, specified in pixels, not included within the aspect ratio calculations. This API already takes into account the difference between a window's size and its content size.

Consider a normal window with an HD video player and associated controls. Perhaps there are 15 pixels of controls on the left edge, 25 pixels of controls on the right edge and 50 pixels of controls below the player. In order to maintain a 16:9 aspect ratio (standard aspect ratio for HD @1920x1080) within the player itself we would call this function with arguments of 16/9 and { width: 40, height: 50 }. The second argument doesn't care where the extra width and height are within the content view--only that they exist. Sum any extra width and height areas you have within the overall content view.

The aspect ratio is not respected when window is resized programmingly with APIs like `win.setSize`.

parameters.name: aspectRatio
parameters.description: The aspect ratio to maintain for some portion of the content view.

parameters.name: extraSize
parameters.description: The extra size not to be included while maintaining the aspect ratio.

instanceMethods.name: setBackgroundColor
instanceMethods.description: Sets the background color of the window. See Setting `backgroundColor`.

parameters.name: backgroundColor
parameters.description: Window's background color as a hexadecimal value, like `#66CD00` or `#FFF` or `#80FFFFFF` (alpha is supported if `transparent` is `true`). Default is `#FFF` (white).

instanceMethods.name: previewFile
instanceMethods.description: Uses Quick Look to preview a file at a given path.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The absolute path to the file to preview with QuickLook. This is important as Quick Look uses the file name and file extension on the path to determine the content type of the file to open.

parameters.name: displayName
parameters.description: The name of the file to display on the Quick Look modal view. This is purely visual and does not affect the content type of the file. Defaults to `path`.

instanceMethods.name: closeFilePreview
instanceMethods.description: Closes the currently open Quick Look panel.

instanceMethods.name: setBounds
instanceMethods.description: Resizes and moves the window to the supplied bounds. Any properties that are not supplied will default to their current values.

instanceMethods.name: getBounds
instanceMethods.description: The `bounds` of the window as `Object`.

instanceMethods.name: getBackgroundColor
instanceMethods.description: Gets the background color of the window. See Setting `backgroundColor`.

instanceMethods.name: setContentBounds
instanceMethods.description: Resizes and moves the window's client area (e.g. the web page) to the supplied bounds.

instanceMethods.name: getContentBounds
instanceMethods.description: The `bounds` of the window's client area as `Object`.

instanceMethods.name: getNormalBounds
instanceMethods.description:
Contains the window bounds of the normal state

**Note:** whatever the current state of the window : maximized, minimized or in fullscreen, this function always returns the position and size of the window in normal state. In normal state, getBounds and getNormalBounds returns the same `Rectangle`.

instanceMethods.name: setEnabled
instanceMethods.description: Disable or enable the window.

instanceMethods.name: isEnabled
instanceMethods.description: whether the window is enabled.

instanceMethods.name: setSize
instanceMethods.description: Resizes the window to `width` and `height`. If `width` or `height` are below any set minimum size constraints the window will snap to its minimum size.

instanceMethods.name: getSize
instanceMethods.description: Contains the window's width and height.

instanceMethods.name: setContentSize
instanceMethods.description: Resizes the window's client area (e.g. the web page) to `width` and `height`.

instanceMethods.name: getContentSize
instanceMethods.description: Contains the window's client area's width and height.

instanceMethods.name: setMinimumSize
instanceMethods.description: Sets the minimum size of window to `width` and `height`.

instanceMethods.name: getMinimumSize
instanceMethods.description: Contains the window's minimum width and height.

instanceMethods.name: setMaximumSize
instanceMethods.description: Sets the maximum size of window to `width` and `height`.

instanceMethods.name: getMaximumSize
instanceMethods.description: Contains the window's maximum width and height.

instanceMethods.name: setResizable
instanceMethods.description: Sets whether the window can be manually resized by the user.

instanceMethods.name: isResizable
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window can be manually resized by the user.

instanceMethods.name: setMovable
instanceMethods.description: Sets whether the window can be moved by user. On Linux does nothing.

instanceMethods.name: isMovable
instanceMethods.description:
Whether the window can be moved by user.

On Linux always returns `true`.

instanceMethods.name: setMinimizable
instanceMethods.description: Sets whether the window can be manually minimized by user. On Linux does nothing.

instanceMethods.name: isMinimizable
instanceMethods.description:
Whether the window can be manually minimized by the user.

On Linux always returns `true`.

instanceMethods.name: setMaximizable
instanceMethods.description: Sets whether the window can be manually maximized by user. On Linux does nothing.

instanceMethods.name: isMaximizable
instanceMethods.description:
Whether the window can be manually maximized by user.

On Linux always returns `true`.

instanceMethods.name: setFullScreenable
instanceMethods.description: Sets whether the maximize/zoom window button toggles fullscreen mode or maximizes the window.

instanceMethods.name: isFullScreenable
instanceMethods.description: Whether the maximize/zoom window button toggles fullscreen mode or maximizes the window.

instanceMethods.name: setClosable
instanceMethods.description: Sets whether the window can be manually closed by user. On Linux does nothing.

instanceMethods.name: isClosable
instanceMethods.description:
Whether the window can be manually closed by user.

On Linux always returns `true`.

instanceMethods.name: setAlwaysOnTop
instanceMethods.description: Sets whether the window should show always on top of other windows. After setting this, the window is still a normal window, not a toolbox window which can not be focused on.

parameters.name: level
parameters.description: Values include `normal`, `floating`, `torn-off-menu`, `modal-panel`, `main-menu`, `status`, `pop-up-menu`, `screen-saver`, and ~~`dock`~~ (Deprecated). The default is `floating` when `flag` is true. The `level` is reset to `normal` when the flag is false. Note that from `floating` to `status` included, the window is placed below the Dock on macOS and below the taskbar on Windows. From `pop-up-menu` to a higher it is shown above the Dock on macOS and above the taskbar on Windows. See the macOS docs for more details.

parameters.name: relativeLevel
parameters.description: The number of layers higher to set this window relative to the given `level`. The default is `0`. Note that Apple discourages setting levels higher than 1 above `screen-saver`.

instanceMethods.name: isAlwaysOnTop
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window is always on top of other windows.

instanceMethods.name: moveAbove
instanceMethods.description: Moves window above the source window in the sense of z-order. If the `mediaSourceId` is not of type window or if the window does not exist then this method throws an error.

parameters.name: mediaSourceId
parameters.description: Window id in the format of DesktopCapturerSource's id. For example "window:1869:0".

instanceMethods.name: moveTop
instanceMethods.description: Moves window to top(z-order) regardless of focus

instanceMethods.name: center
instanceMethods.description: Moves window to the center of the screen.

instanceMethods.name: setPosition
instanceMethods.description: Moves window to `x` and `y`.

instanceMethods.name: getPosition
instanceMethods.description: Contains the window's current position.

instanceMethods.name: setTitle
instanceMethods.description: Changes the title of native window to `title`.

instanceMethods.name: getTitle
instanceMethods.description:
The title of the native window.

**Note:** The title of the web page can be different from the title of the native window.

instanceMethods.name: setSheetOffset
instanceMethods.description: Changes the attachment point for sheets on macOS. By default, sheets are attached just below the window frame, but you may want to display them beneath a HTML-rendered toolbar. For example:

instanceMethods.name: flashFrame
instanceMethods.description: Starts or stops flashing the window to attract user's attention.

instanceMethods.name: setSkipTaskbar
instanceMethods.description: Makes the window not show in the taskbar.

instanceMethods.name: setKiosk
instanceMethods.description: Enters or leaves kiosk mode.

instanceMethods.name: isKiosk
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window is in kiosk mode.

instanceMethods.name: isTabletMode
instanceMethods.description:
Whether the window is in Windows 10 tablet mode.

Since Windows 10 users can use their PC as tablet, under this mode apps can choose to optimize their UI for tablets, such as enlarging the titlebar and hiding titlebar buttons.

This API returns whether the window is in tablet mode, and the `resize` event can be be used to listen to changes to tablet mode.

instanceMethods.name: getMediaSourceId
instanceMethods.description:
Window id in the format of DesktopCapturerSource's id. For example "window:1324:0".

More precisely the format is `window:id:other_id` where `id` is `HWND` on Windows, `CGWindowID` (`uint64_t`) on macOS and `Window` (`unsigned long`) on Linux. `other_id` is used to identify web contents (tabs) so within the same top level window.

instanceMethods.name: getNativeWindowHandle
instanceMethods.description:
The platform-specific handle of the window.

The native type of the handle is `HWND` on Windows, `NSView*` on macOS, and `Window` (`unsigned long`) on Linux.

instanceMethods.name: hookWindowMessage
instanceMethods.description: Hooks a windows message. The `callback` is called when the message is received in the WndProc.

parameters.name: wParam
parameters.description: The `wParam` provided to the WndProc

parameters.name: lParam
parameters.description: The `lParam` provided to the WndProc

instanceMethods.name: isWindowMessageHooked
instanceMethods.description: `true` or `false` depending on whether the message is hooked.

instanceMethods.name: unhookWindowMessage
instanceMethods.description: Unhook the window message.

instanceMethods.name: unhookAllWindowMessages
instanceMethods.description: Unhooks all of the window messages.

instanceMethods.name: setRepresentedFilename
instanceMethods.description: Sets the pathname of the file the window represents, and the icon of the file will show in window's title bar.

instanceMethods.name: getRepresentedFilename
instanceMethods.description: The pathname of the file the window represents.

instanceMethods.name: setDocumentEdited
instanceMethods.description: Specifies whether the window’s document has been edited, and the icon in title bar will become gray when set to `true`.

instanceMethods.name: isDocumentEdited
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window's document has been edited.

instanceMethods.name: capturePage
instanceMethods.description:
Resolves with a NativeImage

Captures a snapshot of the page within `rect`. Omitting `rect` will capture the whole visible page. If the page is not visible, `rect` may be empty.

parameters.name: rect
parameters.description: The bounds to capture

instanceMethods.name: loadURL
instanceMethods.description:
the promise will resolve when the page has finished loading (see `did-finish-load`), and rejects if the page fails to load (see `did-fail-load`).

Same as `webContents.loadURL(url[, options])`.

The `url` can be a remote address (e.g. `http://`) or a path to a local HTML file using the `file://` protocol.

To ensure that file URLs are properly formatted, it is recommended to use Node's `url.format` method:

You can load a URL using a `POST` request with URL-encoded data by doing the following:

properties.name: httpReferrer
properties.description: An HTTP Referrer URL.

properties.name: userAgent
properties.description: A user agent originating the request.

properties.name: extraHeaders
properties.description: Extra headers separated by "\n"

properties.name: baseURLForDataURL
properties.description: Base URL (with trailing path separator) for files to be loaded by the data URL. This is needed only if the specified `url` is a data URL and needs to load other files.

instanceMethods.name: loadFile
instanceMethods.description:
the promise will resolve when the page has finished loading (see `did-finish-load`), and rejects if the page fails to load (see `did-fail-load`).

Same as `webContents.loadFile`, `filePath` should be a path to an HTML file relative to the root of your application.  See the `webContents` docs for more information.

properties.name: query
properties.description: Passed to `url.format()`.

properties.name: search
properties.description: Passed to `url.format()`.

properties.name: hash
properties.description: Passed to `url.format()`.

instanceMethods.name: reload
instanceMethods.description: Same as `webContents.reload`.

instanceMethods.name: setMenu
instanceMethods.description: Sets the `menu` as the window's menu bar.

instanceMethods.name: removeMenu
instanceMethods.description: Remove the window's menu bar.

instanceMethods.name: setProgressBar
instanceMethods.description:
Sets progress value in progress bar. Valid range is [0, 1.0].

Remove progress bar when progress < 0; Change to indeterminate mode when progress > 1.

On Linux platform, only supports Unity desktop environment, you need to specify the `*.desktop` file name to `desktopName` field in `package.json`. By default, it will assume `{app.name}.desktop`.

On Windows, a mode can be passed. Accepted values are `none`, `normal`, `indeterminate`, `error`, and `paused`. If you call `setProgressBar` without a mode set (but with a value within the valid range), `normal` will be assumed.

properties.name: mode
properties.description: Mode for the progress bar. Can be `none`, `normal`, `indeterminate`, `error` or `paused`.

instanceMethods.name: setOverlayIcon
instanceMethods.description: Sets a 16 x 16 pixel overlay onto the current taskbar icon, usually used to convey some sort of application status or to passively notify the user.

parameters.name: overlay
parameters.description: the icon to display on the bottom right corner of the taskbar icon. If this parameter is `null`, the overlay is cleared

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: a description that will be provided to Accessibility screen readers

instanceMethods.name: setHasShadow
instanceMethods.description: Sets whether the window should have a shadow.

instanceMethods.name: hasShadow
instanceMethods.description: Whether the window has a shadow.

instanceMethods.name: setOpacity
instanceMethods.description: Sets the opacity of the window. On Linux, does nothing. Out of bound number values are clamped to the [0, 1] range.

parameters.name: opacity
parameters.description: between 0.0 (fully transparent) and 1.0 (fully opaque)

instanceMethods.name: getOpacity
instanceMethods.description: between 0.0 (fully transparent) and 1.0 (fully opaque). On Linux, always returns 1.

instanceMethods.name: setShape
instanceMethods.description: Setting a window shape determines the area within the window where the system permits drawing and user interaction. Outside of the given region, no pixels will be drawn and no mouse events will be registered. Mouse events outside of the region will not be received by that window, but will fall through to whatever is behind the window.

parameters.name: rects
parameters.description: Sets a shape on the window. Passing an empty list reverts the window to being rectangular.

instanceMethods.name: setThumbarButtons
instanceMethods.description:
Whether the buttons were added successfully

Add a thumbnail toolbar with a specified set of buttons to the thumbnail image of a window in a taskbar button layout. Returns a `Boolean` object indicates whether the thumbnail has been added successfully.

The number of buttons in thumbnail toolbar should be no greater than 7 due to the limited room. Once you setup the thumbnail toolbar, the toolbar cannot be removed due to the platform's limitation. But you can call the API with an empty array to clean the buttons.

The `buttons` is an array of `Button` objects:

* `Button` Object
  * `icon` NativeImage - The icon showing in thumbnail toolbar.
  * `click` Function
  * `tooltip` String (optional) - The text of the button's tooltip.
  * `flags` String[] (optional) - Control specific states and behaviors of the button. By default, it is `['enabled']`.

The `flags` is an array that can include following `String`s:

* `enabled` - The button is active and available to the user.
* `disabled` - The button is disabled. It is present, but has a visual state indicating it will not respond to user action.
* `dismissonclick` - When the button is clicked, the thumbnail window closes immediately.
* `nobackground` - Do not draw a button border, use only the image.
* `hidden` - The button is not shown to the user.
* `noninteractive` - The button is enabled but not interactive; no pressed button state is drawn. This value is intended for instances where the button is used in a notification.

instanceMethods.name: setThumbnailClip
instanceMethods.description: Sets the region of the window to show as the thumbnail image displayed when hovering over the window in the taskbar. You can reset the thumbnail to be the entire window by specifying an empty region: `{ x: 0, y: 0, width: 0, height: 0 }`.

parameters.name: region
parameters.description: Region of the window

instanceMethods.name: setThumbnailToolTip
instanceMethods.description: Sets the toolTip that is displayed when hovering over the window thumbnail in the taskbar.

instanceMethods.name: setAppDetails
instanceMethods.description:
Sets the properties for the window's taskbar button.

**Note:** `relaunchCommand` and `relaunchDisplayName` must always be set together. If one of those properties is not set, then neither will be used.

properties.name: appId
properties.description: Window's App User Model ID. It has to be set, otherwise the other options will have no effect.

properties.name: appIconPath
properties.description: Window's Relaunch Icon.

properties.name: appIconIndex
properties.description: Index of the icon in `appIconPath`. Ignored when `appIconPath` is not set. Default is `0`.

properties.name: relaunchCommand
properties.description: Window's Relaunch Command.

properties.name: relaunchDisplayName
properties.description: Window's Relaunch Display Name.

instanceMethods.name: showDefinitionForSelection
instanceMethods.description: Same as `webContents.showDefinitionForSelection()`.

instanceMethods.name: setIcon
instanceMethods.description: Changes window icon.

instanceMethods.name: setWindowButtonVisibility
instanceMethods.description: Sets whether the window traffic light buttons should be visible.

instanceMethods.name: setAutoHideMenuBar
instanceMethods.description:
Sets whether the window menu bar should hide itself automatically. Once set the menu bar will only show when users press the single `Alt` key.

If the menu bar is already visible, calling `setAutoHideMenuBar(true)` won't hide it immediately.

instanceMethods.name: isMenuBarAutoHide
instanceMethods.description: Whether menu bar automatically hides itself.

instanceMethods.name: setMenuBarVisibility
instanceMethods.description: Sets whether the menu bar should be visible. If the menu bar is auto-hide, users can still bring up the menu bar by pressing the single `Alt` key.

instanceMethods.name: isMenuBarVisible
instanceMethods.description: Whether the menu bar is visible.

instanceMethods.name: setVisibleOnAllWorkspaces
instanceMethods.description:
Sets whether the window should be visible on all workspaces.

**Note:** This API does nothing on Windows.

properties.name: visibleOnFullScreen
properties.description: Sets whether the window should be visible above fullscreen windows.

properties.name: skipTransformProcessType
properties.description: Calling setVisibleOnAllWorkspaces will by default transform the process type between UIElementApplication and ForegroundApplication to ensure the correct behavior. However, this will hide the window and dock for a short time every time it is called. If your window is already of type UIElementApplication, you can bypass this transformation by passing true to skipTransformProcessType.

instanceMethods.name: isVisibleOnAllWorkspaces
instanceMethods.description:
Whether the window is visible on all workspaces.

**Note:** This API always returns false on Windows.

instanceMethods.name: setIgnoreMouseEvents
instanceMethods.description:
Makes the window ignore all mouse events.

All mouse events happened in this window will be passed to the window below this window, but if this window has focus, it will still receive keyboard events.

properties.name: forward
properties.description: If true, forwards mouse move messages to Chromium, enabling mouse related events such as `mouseleave`. Only used when `ignore` is true. If `ignore` is false, forwarding is always disabled regardless of this value.

instanceMethods.name: setContentProtection
instanceMethods.description:
Prevents the window contents from being captured by other apps.

On macOS it sets the NSWindow's sharingType to NSWindowSharingNone. On Windows it calls SetWindowDisplayAffinity with `WDA_EXCLUDEFROMCAPTURE`. For Windows 10 version 2004 and up the window will be removed from capture entirely, older Windows versions behave as if `WDA_MONITOR` is applied capturing a black window.

instanceMethods.name: setFocusable
instanceMethods.description:
Changes whether the window can be focused.

On macOS it does not remove the focus from the window.

instanceMethods.name: setParentWindow
instanceMethods.description: Sets `parent` as current window's parent window, passing `null` will turn current window into a top-level window.

instanceMethods.name: getParentWindow
instanceMethods.description: The parent window.

instanceMethods.name: getChildWindows
instanceMethods.description: All child windows.

instanceMethods.name: setAutoHideCursor
instanceMethods.description: Controls whether to hide cursor when typing.

instanceMethods.name: selectPreviousTab
instanceMethods.description: Selects the previous tab when native tabs are enabled and there are other tabs in the window.

instanceMethods.name: selectNextTab
instanceMethods.description: Selects the next tab when native tabs are enabled and there are other tabs in the window.

instanceMethods.name: mergeAllWindows
instanceMethods.description: Merges all windows into one window with multiple tabs when native tabs are enabled and there is more than one open window.

instanceMethods.name: moveTabToNewWindow
instanceMethods.description: Moves the current tab into a new window if native tabs are enabled and there is more than one tab in the current window.

instanceMethods.name: toggleTabBar
instanceMethods.description: Toggles the visibility of the tab bar if native tabs are enabled and there is only one tab in the current window.

instanceMethods.name: addTabbedWindow
instanceMethods.description: Adds a window as a tab on this window, after the tab for the window instance.

instanceMethods.name: setVibrancy
instanceMethods.description:
Adds a vibrancy effect to the browser window. Passing `null` or an empty string will remove the vibrancy effect on the window.

Note that `appearance-based`, `light`, `dark`, `medium-light`, and `ultra-dark` have been deprecated and will be removed in an upcoming version of macOS.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: Can be `appearance-based`, `light`, `dark`, `titlebar`, `selection`, `menu`, `popover`, `sidebar`, `medium-light`, `ultra-dark`, `header`, `sheet`, `window`, `hud`, `fullscreen-ui`, `tooltip`, `content`, `under-window`, or `under-page`. See the macOS documentation for more details.

instanceMethods.name: setTrafficLightPosition
instanceMethods.description: Set a custom position for the traffic light buttons in frameless window.

instanceMethods.name: getTrafficLightPosition
instanceMethods.description: The custom position for the traffic light buttons in frameless window.

instanceMethods.name: setTouchBar
instanceMethods.description:
Sets the touchBar layout for the current window. Specifying `null` or `undefined` clears the touch bar. This method only has an effect if the machine has a touch bar and is running on macOS 10.12.1+.

**Note:** The TouchBar API is currently experimental and may change or be removed in future Electron releases.

parameters.name: browserView
parameters.description: Attach `browserView` to `win`. If there are other `BrowserView`s attached, they will be removed from this window.

instanceMethods.name: getBrowserView
instanceMethods.description: The `BrowserView` attached to `win`. Returns `null` if one is not attached. Throws an error if multiple `BrowserView`s are attached.

instanceMethods.name: addBrowserView
instanceMethods.description: Replacement API for setBrowserView supporting work with multi browser views.

instanceMethods.name: setTopBrowserView
instanceMethods.description: Raises `browserView` above other `BrowserView`s attached to `win`. Throws an error if `browserView` is not attached to `win`.

instanceMethods.name: getBrowserViews
instanceMethods.description:
an array of all BrowserViews that have been attached with `addBrowserView` or `setBrowserView`.

**Note:** The BrowserView API is currently experimental and may change or be removed in future Electron releases.

instanceProperties.name: webContents
instanceProperties.description:
A `WebContents` object this window owns. All web page related events and operations will be done via it.

See the `webContents` documentation for its methods and events.

instanceProperties.name: id
instanceProperties.description: A `Integer` property representing the unique ID of the window. Each ID is unique among all `BrowserWindow` instances of the entire Electron application.

instanceProperties.name: autoHideMenuBar
instanceProperties.description:
A `Boolean` property that determines whether the window menu bar should hide itself automatically. Once set, the menu bar will only show when users press the single `Alt` key.

If the menu bar is already visible, setting this property to `true` won't hide it immediately.

instanceProperties.name: simpleFullScreen
instanceProperties.description: A `Boolean` property that determines whether the window is in simple (pre-Lion) fullscreen mode.

instanceProperties.name: fullScreen
instanceProperties.description: A `Boolean` property that determines whether the window is in fullscreen mode.

instanceProperties.name: visibleOnAllWorkspaces
instanceProperties.description:
A `Boolean` property that determines whether the window is visible on all workspaces.

**Note:** Always returns false on Windows.

instanceProperties.name: shadow
instanceProperties.description: A `Boolean` property that determines whether the window has a shadow.

instanceProperties.name: menuBarVisible
instanceProperties.description:
A `Boolean` property that determines whether the menu bar should be visible.

**Note:** If the menu bar is auto-hide, users can still bring up the menu bar by pressing the single `Alt` key.

instanceProperties.name: kiosk
instanceProperties.description: A `Boolean` property that determines whether the window is in kiosk mode.

instanceProperties.name: documentEdited
instanceProperties.description:
A `Boolean` property that specifies whether the window’s document has been edited.

The icon in title bar will become gray when set to `true`.

instanceProperties.name: representedFilename
instanceProperties.description: A `String` property that determines the pathname of the file the window represents, and the icon of the file will show in window's title bar.

instanceProperties.name: title
instanceProperties.description:
A `String` property that determines the title of the native window.

**Note:** The title of the web page can be different from the title of the native window.

instanceProperties.name: minimizable
instanceProperties.description:
A `Boolean` property that determines whether the window can be manually minimized by user.

On Linux the setter is a no-op, although the getter returns `true`.

instanceProperties.name: maximizable
instanceProperties.description:
A `Boolean` property that determines whether the window can be manually maximized by user.

On Linux the setter is a no-op, although the getter returns `true`.

instanceProperties.name: fullScreenable
instanceProperties.description: A `Boolean` property that determines whether the maximize/zoom window button toggles fullscreen mode or maximizes the window.

instanceProperties.name: resizable
instanceProperties.description: A `Boolean` property that determines whether the window can be manually resized by user.

instanceProperties.name: closable
instanceProperties.description:
A `Boolean` property that determines whether the window can be manually closed by user.

On Linux the setter is a no-op, although the getter returns `true`.

instanceProperties.name: movable
instanceProperties.description:
A `Boolean` property that determines Whether the window can be moved by user.

On Linux the setter is a no-op, although the getter returns `true`.

instanceProperties.name: excludedFromShownWindowsMenu
instanceProperties.description: A `Boolean` property that determines whether the window is excluded from the application’s Windows menu. `false` by default.

instanceProperties.name: accessibleTitle
instanceProperties.description: A `String` property that defines an alternative title provided only to accessibility tools such as screen readers. This string is not directly visible to users.

instanceEvents.name: page-title-updated
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the document changed its title, calling `event.preventDefault()` will prevent the native window's title from changing. `explicitSet` is false when title is synthesized from file URL.

instanceEvents.name: close
instanceEvents.description:
Emitted when the window is going to be closed. It's emitted before the `beforeunload` and `unload` event of the DOM. Calling `event.preventDefault()` will cancel the close.

Usually you would want to use the `beforeunload` handler to decide whether the window should be closed, which will also be called when the window is reloaded. In Electron, returning any value other than `undefined` would cancel the close. For example:

_**Note**: There is a subtle difference between the behaviors of `window.onbeforeunload = handler` and `window.addEventListener('beforeunload', handler)`. It is recommended to always set the `event.returnValue` explicitly, instead of only returning a value, as the former works more consistently within Electron._

instanceEvents.name: closed
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window is closed. After you have received this event you should remove the reference to the window and avoid using it any more.

instanceEvents.name: session-end
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when window session is going to end due to force shutdown or machine restart or session log off.

instanceEvents.name: unresponsive
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the web page becomes unresponsive.

instanceEvents.name: responsive
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the unresponsive web page becomes responsive again.

instanceEvents.name: blur
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window loses focus.

instanceEvents.name: focus
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window gains focus.

instanceEvents.name: show
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window is shown.

instanceEvents.name: hide
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window is hidden.

instanceEvents.name: ready-to-show
instanceEvents.description:
Emitted when the web page has been rendered (while not being shown) and window can be displayed without a visual flash.

Please note that using this event implies that the renderer will be considered "visible" and paint even though `show` is false.  This event will never fire if you use `paintWhenInitiallyHidden: false`

instanceEvents.name: maximize
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when window is maximized.

instanceEvents.name: unmaximize
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window exits from a maximized state.

instanceEvents.name: minimize
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window is minimized.

instanceEvents.name: restore
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window is restored from a minimized state.

instanceEvents.name: will-resize
instanceEvents.description:
Emitted before the window is resized. Calling `event.preventDefault()` will prevent the window from being resized.

Note that this is only emitted when the window is being resized manually. Resizing the window with `setBounds`/`setSize` will not emit this event.

parameters.name: newBounds
parameters.description: Size the window is being resized to.

instanceEvents.name: resize
instanceEvents.description: Emitted after the window has been resized.

instanceEvents.name: resized
instanceEvents.description:
Emitted once when the window has finished being resized.

This is usually emitted when the window has been resized manually. On macOS, resizing the window with `setBounds`/`setSize` and setting the `animate` parameter to `true` will also emit this event once resizing has finished.

instanceEvents.name: will-move
instanceEvents.description:
Emitted before the window is moved. On Windows, calling `event.preventDefault()` will prevent the window from being moved.

Note that this is only emitted when the window is being resized manually. Resizing the window with `setBounds`/`setSize` will not emit this event.

parameters.name: newBounds
parameters.description: Location the window is being moved to.

instanceEvents.name: move
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window is being moved to a new position.

instanceEvents.name: moved
instanceEvents.description:
Emitted once when the window is moved to a new position.

__Note__: On macOS this event is an alias of `move`.

instanceEvents.name: enter-full-screen
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window enters a full-screen state.

instanceEvents.name: leave-full-screen
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window leaves a full-screen state.

instanceEvents.name: enter-html-full-screen
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window enters a full-screen state triggered by HTML API.

instanceEvents.name: leave-html-full-screen
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window leaves a full-screen state triggered by HTML API.

instanceEvents.name: always-on-top-changed
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window is set or unset to show always on top of other windows.

instanceEvents.name: app-command
instanceEvents.description:
Emitted when an App Command is invoked. These are typically related to keyboard media keys or browser commands, as well as the "Back" button built into some mice on Windows.

Commands are lowercased, underscores are replaced with hyphens, and the `APPCOMMAND_` prefix is stripped off. e.g. `APPCOMMAND_BROWSER_BACKWARD` is emitted as `browser-backward`.

The following app commands are explicitly supported on Linux:

* `browser-backward`
* `browser-forward`

instanceEvents.name: scroll-touch-begin
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when scroll wheel event phase has begun.

instanceEvents.name: scroll-touch-end
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when scroll wheel event phase has ended.

instanceEvents.name: scroll-touch-edge
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when scroll wheel event phase filed upon reaching the edge of element.

instanceEvents.name: swipe
instanceEvents.description:
Emitted on 3-finger swipe. Possible directions are `up`, `right`, `down`, `left`.

The method underlying this event is built to handle older macOS-style trackpad swiping, where the content on the screen doesn't move with the swipe. Most macOS trackpads are not configured to allow this kind of swiping anymore, so in order for it to emit properly the 'Swipe between pages' preference in `System Preferences > Trackpad > More Gestures` must be set to 'Swipe with two or three fingers'.

instanceEvents.name: rotate-gesture
instanceEvents.description: Emitted on trackpad rotation gesture. Continually emitted until rotation gesture is ended. The `rotation` value on each emission is the angle in degrees rotated since the last emission. The last emitted event upon a rotation gesture will always be of value `0`. Counter-clockwise rotation values are positive, while clockwise ones are negative.

instanceEvents.name: sheet-begin
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window opens a sheet.

instanceEvents.name: sheet-end
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the window has closed a sheet.

instanceEvents.name: new-window-for-tab
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the native new tab button is clicked.

instanceEvents.name: system-context-menu
instanceEvents.description:
Emitted when the system context menu is triggered on the window, this is normally only triggered when the user right clicks on the non-client area of your window.  This is the window titlebar or any area you have declared as `-webkit-app-region: drag` in a frameless window.

Calling `event.preventDefault()` will prevent the menu from being displayed.

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: The screen coordinates the context menu was triggered at

name: ClientRequest
description:
> Make HTTP/HTTPS requests.

Process: Main

`ClientRequest` implements the Writable Stream interface and is therefore an EventEmitter.

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: If `options` is a String, it is interpreted as the request URL. If it is an object, it is expected to fully specify an HTTP request via the following properties:

properties.name: method
properties.description: The HTTP request method. Defaults to the GET method.

properties.name: url
properties.description: The request URL. Must be provided in the absolute form with the protocol scheme specified as http or https.

properties.name: session
properties.description: The `Session` instance with which the request is associated.

properties.name: partition
properties.description: The name of the `partition` with which the request is associated. Defaults to the empty string. The `session` option supersedes `partition`. Thus if a `session` is explicitly specified, `partition` is ignored.

properties.name: credentials
properties.description: Can be `include` or `omit`. Whether to send credentials with this request. If set to `include`, credentials from the session associated with the request will be used. If set to `omit`, credentials will not be sent with the request (and the `'login'` event will not be triggered in the event of a 401). This matches the behavior of the fetch option of the same name. If this option is not specified, authentication data from the session will be sent, and cookies will not be sent (unless `useSessionCookies` is set).

properties.name: useSessionCookies
properties.description: Whether to send cookies with this request from the provided session. If `credentials` is specified, this option has no effect. Default is `false`.

properties.name: protocol
properties.description: Can be `http:` or `https:`. The protocol scheme in the form 'scheme:'. Defaults to 'http:'.

properties.name: host
properties.description: The server host provided as a concatenation of the hostname and the port number 'hostname:port'.

properties.name: hostname
properties.description: The server host name.

properties.name: port
properties.description: The server's listening port number.

properties.name: path
properties.description: The path part of the request URL.

properties.name: redirect
properties.description: Can be `follow`, `error` or `manual`. The redirect mode for this request. When mode is `error`, any redirection will be aborted. When mode is `manual` the redirection will be cancelled unless `request.followRedirect` is invoked synchronously during the `redirect` event.  Defaults to `follow`.

properties.name: origin
properties.description: The origin URL of the request.

instanceMethods.name: setHeader
instanceMethods.description:
Adds an extra HTTP header. The header name will be issued as-is without lowercasing. It can be called only before first write. Calling this method after the first write will throw an error. If the passed value is not a `String`, its `toString()` method will be called to obtain the final value.

Certain headers are restricted from being set by apps. These headers are listed below. More information on restricted headers can be found in Chromium's header utils.

* `Content-Length`
* `Host`
* `Trailer` or `Te`
* `Upgrade`
* `Cookie2`
* `Keep-Alive`
* `Transfer-Encoding`

Additionally, setting the `Connection` header to the value `upgrade` is also disallowed.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: An extra HTTP header name.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: An extra HTTP header value.

instanceMethods.name: getHeader
instanceMethods.description: The value of a previously set extra header name.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Specify an extra header name.

instanceMethods.name: removeHeader
instanceMethods.description: Removes a previously set extra header name. This method can be called only before first write. Trying to call it after the first write will throw an error.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Specify an extra header name.

instanceMethods.name: write
instanceMethods.description:
`callback` is essentially a dummy function introduced in the purpose of keeping similarity with the Node.js API. It is called asynchronously in the next tick after `chunk` content have been delivered to the Chromium networking layer. Contrary to the Node.js implementation, it is not guaranteed that `chunk` content have been flushed on the wire before `callback` is called.

Adds a chunk of data to the request body. The first write operation may cause the request headers to be issued on the wire. After the first write operation, it is not allowed to add or remove a custom header.

parameters.name: chunk
parameters.description: A chunk of the request body's data. If it is a string, it is converted into a Buffer using the specified encoding.

parameters.name: encoding
parameters.description: Used to convert string chunks into Buffer objects. Defaults to 'utf-8'.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: Called after the write operation ends.

instanceMethods.name: end
instanceMethods.description: Sends the last chunk of the request data. Subsequent write or end operations will not be allowed. The `finish` event is emitted just after the end operation.

instanceMethods.name: abort
instanceMethods.description: Cancels an ongoing HTTP transaction. If the request has already emitted the `close` event, the abort operation will have no effect. Otherwise an ongoing event will emit `abort` and `close` events. Additionally, if there is an ongoing response object,it will emit the `aborted` event.

instanceMethods.name: followRedirect
instanceMethods.description: Continues any pending redirection. Can only be called during a `'redirect'` event.

instanceMethods.name: getUploadProgress
instanceMethods.description:
* `active` Boolean - Whether the request is currently active. If this is false no other properties will be set
* `started` Boolean - Whether the upload has started. If this is false both `current` and `total` will be set to 0.
* `current` Integer - The number of bytes that have been uploaded so far
* `total` Integer - The number of bytes that will be uploaded this request

You can use this method in conjunction with `POST` requests to get the progress of a file upload or other data transfer.

properties.name: active
properties.description: Whether the request is currently active. If this is false no other properties will be set

properties.name: started
properties.description: Whether the upload has started. If this is false both `current` and `total` will be set to 0.

properties.name: current
properties.description: The number of bytes that have been uploaded so far

properties.name: total
properties.description: The number of bytes that will be uploaded this request

instanceProperties.name: chunkedEncoding
instanceProperties.description:
A `Boolean` specifying whether the request will use HTTP chunked transfer encoding or not. Defaults to false. The property is readable and writable, however it can be set only before the first write operation as the HTTP headers are not yet put on the wire. Trying to set the `chunkedEncoding` property after the first write will throw an error.

Using chunked encoding is strongly recommended if you need to send a large request body as data will be streamed in small chunks instead of being internally buffered inside Electron process memory.

parameters.name: response
parameters.description: An object representing the HTTP response message.

instanceEvents.name: login
instanceEvents.description:
Emitted when an authenticating proxy is asking for user credentials.

The `callback` function is expected to be called back with user credentials:

* `username` String
* `password` String

Providing empty credentials will cancel the request and report an authentication error on the response object:

instanceEvents.name: finish
instanceEvents.description: Emitted just after the last chunk of the `request`'s data has been written into the `request` object.

instanceEvents.name: abort
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the `request` is aborted. The `abort` event will not be fired if the `request` is already closed.

instanceEvents.name: error
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the `net` module fails to issue a network request. Typically when the `request` object emits an `error` event, a `close` event will subsequently follow and no response object will be provided.

parameters.name: error
parameters.description: an error object providing some information about the failure.

instanceEvents.name: close
instanceEvents.description: Emitted as the last event in the HTTP request-response transaction. The `close` event indicates that no more events will be emitted on either the `request` or `response` objects.

instanceEvents.name: redirect
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the server returns a redirect response (e.g. 301 Moved Permanently). Calling `request.followRedirect` will continue with the redirection.  If this event is handled, `request.followRedirect` must be called **synchronously**, otherwise the request will be cancelled.

name: clipboard
description:
> Perform copy and paste operations on the system clipboard.

Process: Main, Renderer

On Linux, there is also a `selection` clipboard. To manipulate it you need to pass `selection` to each method:

methods.name: readText
methods.description: The content in the clipboard as plain text.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: Can be `selection` or `clipboard`; default is 'clipboard'. `selection` is only available on Linux.

methods.name: writeText
methods.description: Writes the `text` into the clipboard as plain text.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: Can be `selection` or `clipboard`; default is 'clipboard'. `selection` is only available on Linux.

methods.name: readHTML
methods.description: The content in the clipboard as markup.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: Can be `selection` or `clipboard`; default is 'clipboard'. `selection` is only available on Linux.

methods.name: writeHTML
methods.description: Writes `markup` to the clipboard.

name: contentTracing
description:
> Collect tracing data from Chromium to find performance bottlenecks and slow operations.

Process: Main

This module does not include a web interface. To view recorded traces, use trace viewer, available at `chrome://tracing` in Chrome.

**Note:** You should not use this module until the `ready` event of the app module is emitted.

methods.name: getCategories
methods.description:
resolves with an array of category groups once all child processes have acknowledged the `getCategories` request

Get a set of category groups. The category groups can change as new code paths are reached. See also the list of built-in tracing categories.

> **NOTE:** Electron adds a non-default tracing category called `"electron"`. This category can be used to capture Electron-specific tracing events.

methods.name: startRecording
methods.description:
resolved once all child processes have acknowledged the `startRecording` request.

Start recording on all processes.

Recording begins immediately locally and asynchronously on child processes as soon as they receive the EnableRecording request.

If a recording is already running, the promise will be immediately resolved, as only one trace operation can be in progress at a time.

methods.name: stopRecording
methods.description:
resolves with a path to a file that contains the traced data once all child processes have acknowledged the `stopRecording` request

Stop recording on all processes.

Child processes typically cache trace data and only rarely flush and send trace data back to the main process. This helps to minimize the runtime overhead of tracing since sending trace data over IPC can be an expensive operation. So, to end tracing, Chromium asynchronously asks all child processes to flush any pending trace data.

Trace data will be written into `resultFilePath`. If `resultFilePath` is empty or not provided, trace data will be written to a temporary file, and the path will be returned in the promise.

methods.name: getTraceBufferUsage
methods.description:
Resolves with an object containing the `value` and `percentage` of trace buffer maximum usage

* `value` Number
* `percentage` Number

Get the maximum usage across processes of trace buffer as a percentage of the full state.

name: contextBridge
description:
> Create a safe, bi-directional, synchronous bridge across isolated contexts

Process: Renderer

An example of exposing an API to a renderer from an isolated preload script is given below:

```
// Preload (Isolated World)
const { contextBridge, ipcRenderer } = require('electron')

contextBridge.exposeInMainWorld(
  'electron',
  {
    doThing: () => ipcRenderer.send('do-a-thing')
  }
)
```

### Glossary



### Main World

The "Main World" is the JavaScript context that your main renderer code runs in. By default, the page you load in your renderer executes code in this world.

### Isolated World

When `contextIsolation` is enabled in your `webPreferences` (this is the default behavior since Electron 12.0.0), your `preload` scripts run in an "Isolated World".  You can read more about context isolation and what it affects in the security docs.

name: crashReporter
description:
> Submit crash reports to a remote server.

Process: Main, Renderer

The following is an example of setting up Electron to automatically submit crash reports to a remote server:

```
const { crashReporter } = require('electron')

crashReporter.start({ submitURL: 'https://your-domain.com/url-to-submit' })
```

For setting up a server to accept and process crash reports, you can use following projects:

* socorro
* mini-breakpad-server

Or use a 3rd party hosted solution:

* Backtrace
* Sentry
* BugSplat

Crash reports are stored temporarily before being uploaded in a directory underneath the app's user data directory (called 'Crashpad' on Windows and Mac, or 'Crash Reports' on Linux). You can override this directory by calling `app.setPath('crashDumps', '/path/to/crashes')` before starting the crash reporter.

On Windows and macOS, Electron uses crashpad to monitor and report crashes. On Linux, Electron uses breakpad. This is an implementation detail driven by Chromium, and it may change in future. In particular, crashpad is newer and will likely eventually replace breakpad on all platforms.

### Note about Node child processes on Linux

If you are using the Node.js `child_process` module and want to report crashes from those processes on Linux, there is an extra step you will need to take to properly initialize the crash reporter in the child process. This is not necessary on Mac or Windows, as those platforms use Crashpad, which automatically monitors child processes.

Since `require('electron')` is not available in Node child processes, the following APIs are available on the `process` object in Node child processes. Note that, on Linux, each Node child process has its own separate instance of the breakpad crash reporter. This is dissimilar to renderer child processes, which have a "stub" breakpad reporter which returns information to the main process for reporting.

### `process.crashReporter.start(options)`

See `crashReporter.start()`.

### `process.crashReporter.getParameters()`

See `crashReporter.getParameters()`.

### `process.crashReporter.addExtraParameter(key, value)`

See `crashReporter.addExtraParameter(key, value)`.

### `process.crashReporter.removeExtraParameter(key)`

See `crashReporter.removeExtraParameter(key)`.

methods.name: start
methods.description:
This method must be called before using any other `crashReporter` APIs. Once initialized this way, the crashpad handler collects crashes from all subsequently created processes. The crash reporter cannot be disabled once started.

This method should be called as early as possible in app startup, preferably before `app.on('ready')`. If the crash reporter is not initialized at the time a renderer process is created, then that renderer process will not be monitored by the crash reporter.

**Note:** You can test out the crash reporter by generating a crash using `process.crash()`.

**Note:** If you need to send additional/updated `extra` parameters after your first call `start` you can call `addExtraParameter`.

**Note:** Parameters passed in `extra`, `globalExtra` or set with `addExtraParameter` have limits on the length of the keys and values. Key names must be at most 39 bytes long, and values must be no longer than 127 bytes. Keys with names longer than the maximum will be silently ignored. Key values longer than the maximum length will be truncated.

**Note:** This method is only available in the main process.

properties.name: submitURL
properties.description: URL that crash reports will be sent to as POST. Required unless `uploadToServer` is `false`.

properties.name: productName
properties.description: Defaults to `app.name`.

properties.name: companyName
properties.description: Deprecated alias for `{ globalExtra: { _companyName: ... } }`.

properties.name: uploadToServer
properties.description: Whether crash reports should be sent to the server. If false, crash reports will be collected and stored in the crashes directory, but not uploaded. Default is `true`.

properties.name: ignoreSystemCrashHandler
properties.description: If true, crashes generated in the main process will not be forwarded to the system crash handler. Default is `false`.

properties.name: rateLimit
properties.description: If true, limit the number of crashes uploaded to 1/hour. Default is `false`.

properties.name: compress
properties.description: If true, crash reports will be compressed and uploaded with `Content-Encoding: gzip`. Default is `true`.

properties.name: extra
properties.description: Extra string key/value annotations that will be sent along with crash reports that are generated in the main process. Only string values are supported. Crashes generated in child processes will not contain these extra parameters to crash reports generated from child processes, call `addExtraParameter` from the child process.

properties.name: globalExtra
properties.description: Extra string key/value annotations that will be sent along with any crash reports generated in any process. These annotations cannot be changed once the crash reporter has been started. If a key is present in both the global extra parameters and the process-specific extra parameters, then the global one will take precedence. By default, `productName` and the app version are included, as well as the Electron version.

methods.name: getLastCrashReport
methods.description:
The date and ID of the last crash report. Only crash reports that have been uploaded will be returned; even if a crash report is present on disk it will not be returned until it is uploaded. In the case that there are no uploaded reports, `null` is returned.

**Note:** This method is only available in the main process.

methods.name: getUploadedReports
methods.description:
Returns all uploaded crash reports. Each report contains the date and uploaded ID.

**Note:** This method is only available in the main process.

methods.name: getUploadToServer
methods.description:
Whether reports should be submitted to the server. Set through the `start` method or `setUploadToServer`.

**Note:** This method is only available in the main process.

methods.name: setUploadToServer
methods.description:
This would normally be controlled by user preferences. This has no effect if called before `start` is called.

**Note:** This method is only available in the main process.

parameters.name: uploadToServer
parameters.description: Whether reports should be submitted to the server.

methods.name: addExtraParameter
methods.description:
Set an extra parameter to be sent with the crash report. The values specified here will be sent in addition to any values set via the `extra` option when `start` was called.

Parameters added in this fashion (or via the `extra` parameter to `crashReporter.start`) are specific to the calling process. Adding extra parameters in the main process will not cause those parameters to be sent along with crashes from renderer or other child processes. Similarly, adding extra parameters in a renderer process will not result in those parameters being sent with crashes that occur in other renderer processes or in the main process.

**Note:** Parameters have limits on the length of the keys and values. Key names must be no longer than 39 bytes, and values must be no longer than 20320 bytes. Keys with names longer than the maximum will be silently ignored. Key values longer than the maximum length will be truncated.

**Note:** On linux values that are longer than 127 bytes will be chunked into multiple keys, each 127 bytes in length.  E.g. `addExtraParameter('foo', 'a'.repeat(130))` will result in two chunked keys `foo__1` and `foo__2`, the first will contain the first 127 bytes and the second will contain the remaining 3 bytes.  On your crash reporting backend you should stitch together keys in this format.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Parameter key, must be no longer than 39 bytes.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: Parameter value, must be no longer than 127 bytes.

methods.name: removeExtraParameter
methods.description: Remove an extra parameter from the current set of parameters. Future crashes will not include this parameter.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Parameter key, must be no longer than 39 bytes.

methods.name: getParameters
methods.description: The current 'extra' parameters of the crash reporter.

name: dialog
description:
> Display native system dialogs for opening and saving files, alerting, etc.

Process: Main

An example of showing a dialog to select multiple files:

methods.name: showOpenDialogSync
methods.description:
the file paths chosen by the user; if the dialog is cancelled it returns `undefined`.

The `browserWindow` argument allows the dialog to attach itself to a parent window, making it modal.

The `filters` specifies an array of file types that can be displayed or selected when you want to limit the user to a specific type. For example:

The `extensions` array should contain extensions without wildcards or dots (e.g. `'png'` is good but `'.png'` and `'*.png'` are bad). To show all files, use the `'*'` wildcard (no other wildcard is supported).

**Note:** On Windows and Linux an open dialog can not be both a file selector and a directory selector, so if you set `properties` to `['openFile', 'openDirectory']` on these platforms, a directory selector will be shown.

properties.name: buttonLabel
properties.description: Custom label for the confirmation button, when left empty the default label will be used.

properties.name: properties
properties.description: Contains which features the dialog should use. The following values are supported:

possibleValues.description: Allow files to be selected.
Allow directories to be selected.
Allow multiple paths to be selected.
Show hidden files in dialog.
Allow creating new directories from dialog.

Prompt for creation if the file path entered in the dialog does not exist. This does not actually create the file at the path but allows non-existent paths to be returned that should be created by the application.
Disable the automatic alias (symlink) path resolution. Selected aliases will now return the alias path instead of their target path.
Treat packages, such as `.app` folders, as a directory instead of a file.
Do not add the item being opened to the recent documents list.

properties.name: message
properties.description: Message to display above input boxes.

properties.name: securityScopedBookmarks
properties.description: Create security scoped bookmarks when packaged for the Mac App Store.

methods.name: showOpenDialog
methods.description:
Resolve with an object containing the following:

* `canceled` Boolean - whether or not the dialog was canceled.
* `filePaths` String[] - An array of file paths chosen by the user. If the dialog is cancelled this will be an empty array.
* `bookmarks` String[] (optional) _macOS_ _mas_ - An array matching the `filePaths` array of base64 encoded strings which contains security scoped bookmark data. `securityScopedBookmarks` must be enabled for this to be populated. (For return values, see table here.)

The `browserWindow` argument allows the dialog to attach itself to a parent window, making it modal.

The `filters` specifies an array of file types that can be displayed or selected when you want to limit the user to a specific type. For example:

The `extensions` array should contain extensions without wildcards or dots (e.g. `'png'` is good but `'.png'` and `'*.png'` are bad). To show all files, use the `'*'` wildcard (no other wildcard is supported).

**Note:** On Windows and Linux an open dialog can not be both a file selector and a directory selector, so if you set `properties` to `['openFile', 'openDirectory']` on these platforms, a directory selector will be shown.

properties.name: buttonLabel
properties.description: Custom label for the confirmation button, when left empty the default label will be used.

properties.name: properties
properties.description: Contains which features the dialog should use. The following values are supported:

possibleValues.description: Allow files to be selected.
Allow directories to be selected.
Allow multiple paths to be selected.
Show hidden files in dialog.
Allow creating new directories from dialog.

Prompt for creation if the file path entered in the dialog does not exist. This does not actually create the file at the path but allows non-existent paths to be returned that should be created by the application.
Disable the automatic alias (symlink) path resolution. Selected aliases will now return the alias path instead of their target path.
Treat packages, such as `.app` folders, as a directory instead of a file.
Do not add the item being opened to the recent documents list.
